title: Source maps returned by loaders are ignored for asset modules
body:
<!-- Please don't delete this template because we'll close your issue -->
<!-- Before creating an issue please make sure you are using the latest version of webpack. -->

# Bug report

When a source file is bundled as an asset module (e.g. `asset/resource`) using one or more loaders that returns a source map, the source map is discarded. Some types of assets (such as CSS files transpiled from SCSS/LESS/etc.) benefit from having source maps, so it doesn't make sense to assume that no asset will ever have a source map.

For example, `sass-loader` can be used to produce `.css` asset files from `.scss` source files. (This is in contrast to using something like `css-loader`/`style-loader`...sometimes a large website may need to reference site-wide static styles instead of having a script import them.)

**What is the current behavior?**

Webpack assumes all modules with a type starting with `asset/` (such as `asset/resource`) are "binary", and discards any source maps returned by loaders for these modules.

In my case, `sass-loader` returns source maps generated by the SASS implementation, which `NormalModule.js` retrieves as such: 

https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/ac8e83a4a2984ed977fd6c23a609da5cb43da492/lib/NormalModule.js#L851-L853

At this point, `source` is of type `string` (not `Buffer`), and `sourceMap` is a valid source map object.

However, several lines later, the `source` string gets converted to a `Buffer` because the constructor for `NormalModule` sets `this.binary` to `true` for all asset modules:

https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/ac8e83a4a2984ed977fd6c23a609da5cb43da492/lib/NormalModule.js#L315
https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/ac8e83a4a2984ed977fd6c23a609da5cb43da492/lib/NormalModule.js#L870-L875

This causes `createSource` to ignore the source map passed into it and return a `RawSource` for the buffer:

https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/ac8e83a4a2984ed977fd6c23a609da5cb43da492/lib/NormalModule.js#L782-L796

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce.**

I can't provide my exact configuration due to proprietary company information, but this is reproducible with any Webpack configuration that uses SASS for asset modules.

- Set up `sass-loader` in a rule for modules with `type: "asset/resource"`. This will need the `sass-loader` and `sass-embedded` packages to be installed.
  ```js
  {
    test: /\.scss$/i,
    type: "asset/resource",
    use: [
      {
        loader: "sass-loader",
        options: {
          api: "modern",
          sourceMap: true,
          sassOptions: {
            sourceMapIncludeSources: true,
          },
        },
      },
    ],
  }
  ```
- Enable Webpack's source maps, e.g. with `devtool: "inline-source-map"`
- Provide a `.scss` file as an entry point
- Run the Webpack compiler
- View the `.css` file in the output directory and observe that it does not contain a source map file adjacent to it, nor does it contain an inline source map comment

**What is the expected behavior?**

Loaders for Asset Modules should be able to return a source map for certain types of assets, and these source maps should be included just like they would be for JavaScript modules instead of being unconditionally ignored.

If I change line 872 in `NormalModule.js` to the following, the source maps from SASS start working as expected:
```js
    (this.binary && !sourceMap) ? asBuffer(source) : asString(source),
```

Obviously this is not suitable as a one-size-fits-all fix; it's a hacky workaround that fixes the problem in my specific situation. Non-text assets (and even many text assets) would not be compatible with source maps (although I wouldn't expect loaders for these asset types to return a source map in the first place).

Perhaps there needs to be a way to opt into source maps on a per-module-rule basis, possibly in the `generator` settings? 

<!-- "It should work" is not a helpful explanation -->
<!-- Explain exactly how it should behave -->

**Other relevant information:**
webpack version:  5.91.0
Node.js version: 20.13.1
Operating System: Windows 10 x64 (version 22H2)
Additional tools:
- `sass-loader = 14.2.1`
- `sass-embedded = 1.77.2`
